name: Reeves's Muntjac
description: The muntjac is small, with reddish-brown fur and a short tail, black on top and white underneath. Males differ from females by having short antlers and long canines. Both have raised, fur-covered bony ridges on their foreheads, ending in antler bases in males and a tuft of longer fur in females.
spread_note: East Asia (southeast China and Taiwan); introduced to the wild in Great Britain in the 20th century, where it thrives
food_note: Various plant parts, eggs, carrion, small vertebrates
image_alt: Reeves's Muntjac, photo: Prague Zoo Archive
proportions: Body length 70–83 cm; tail length 8–12 cm; shoulder height 35–40 cm; weight 12–27 kg
attractions: Though its appearance might not suggest it, the small Reeves’s muntjac belongs to the deer family. Wild muntjacs inhabit territories marked with preorbital gland secretions, which males defend. In fights, males use their long canines and short antlers, which grow from elongated, fur-covered pedicles. In dense undergrowth, they move through a network of tunnels they’ve trampled. Surprisingly, they are omnivorous, capable of hunting smaller vertebrates, including ground birds. Newborn young are spotted, like European deer, gradually transitioning to the uniform brown coat of adults.
breeding: We acquired our first muntjac in 2005 from Plzeň Zoo. We now keep a trio—a female born here in 2010, another from Cologne Zoo, and a male from Hamburg.
